name: The Carter Center
mission: It seeks to prevent and resolve conflicts, enhance freedom and democracy, and improve health.
theoryOfChange: The Carter Center has a 'Peace Programs Strategic Plan' published in April 2022. This document outlines their strategic direction for the next five years, detailing new programming tools and approaches. It explicitly states that an accompanying implementation plan will operationalize the key elements and set specific targets for measuring success. The plan also commits to systematically tracking activities, outputs, and outcomes, and developing monitoring, evaluation, and learning (MEL) resources and capabilities, including creating MEL minimum standards across program areas. Additionally, their 'Human Rights' and 'Democracy Program' pages on the website mention strategic objectives that guide their work and a focus on measuring impact.
zakatClaimEvidence: Organization is in zakat denylist (partners but doesn't collect directly)

components.improvement_suggestion: Add a dedicated zakat page or program and highlight humanitarian dimensions of your work

components.improvement_suggestion: Build working capital reserves to 1-3 months of operating expenses

components.improvement_suggestion: Seek external evaluation or track outcomes for 3+ years

all_citations.claim: The Carter Center seeks to prevent and resolve conflicts, enhance freedom and democracy, and improve health.
The organization accepts general charitable donations (sadaqah) for its humanitarian missions.
The organization reported total revenue of $153,773,756 and operates major programs in conflict resolution and democracy.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a 63/100 reflecting high financial stability and program efficiency, balanced by a medium alignment score for specific donor demographics.
areas_for_improvement: Limited specific alignment with traditional Muslim donor priorities
Moderate data confidence regarding long-term impact metrics

dimension_explanations.alignment: The organization is classified as sadaqah-eligible, offering a medium fit for donors interested in humanitarian cause urgency [2]. While it has a strong track record in international diplomacy, its alignment with specific religious giving frameworks is moderate [1].
dimension_explanations.impact: The Center demonstrates high effectiveness through its capacity-building model, maintaining a total revenue of $153,773,756 to support its global health and peace programs [3]. With a program expense ratio of 81.4%, the organization prioritizes direct service delivery over administrative overhead [1].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Carter Center Inc works to advance global peace and health through conflict resolution, democracy enhancement, and disease prevention.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 81.4% ensuring most funds reach mission-critical work
Exceptional fundraising efficiency at $0.08 per $1 raised
Extensive financial runway with 91.0 months of working capital
baseline_narrative.summary: Founded by former U.S. President Jimmy Carter and Rosalynn Carter, the organization seeks to prevent and resolve conflicts, enhance freedom and democracy, and improve global health [1]. The Center operates major initiatives including the Conflict Resolution Program and the Democracy Program to foster international stability [3].

areas_for_improvement.context: The organization holds <cite id="10">91.0 months of operating reserves</cite>, which significantly exceeds the standard 1-3 month recommendation for non-profits.
While the Center tracks internal metrics, it currently lacks <cite id="15">verified 3rd-party outcome evaluations</cite> for its long-term impact tracking.

bbb_assessment.summary: The organization has a <cite id="16">BBB Wise Giving Alliance profile</cite> but has not yet been verified against all 20 standards.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization manages large-scale, multi-decade health eradication goals that require long-term financial commitments.
risk_factors: <cite id="10">Working capital reserves exceed 7 years of operations</cite>
case_against.summary: The primary concern is the <cite id="10">excessive accumulation of net assets</cite> relative to annual spending, which may suggest a lower immediate funding gap.

confidence.notes: Financial data is highly reliable, but impact and transparency metrics are limited.

alignment.explanation: The organization aligns with humanitarian values through <cite id="17">international service and aid to travelers (ibn sabil)</cite> contexts.
alignment.improvement: The charity could improve alignment by <cite id="18">highlighting the humanitarian dimensions of its work</cite> specifically for Muslim donor audiences.

credibility.explanation: Donors can trust the organization due to its <cite id="1">44-year track record</cite> and leadership by a <cite id="13">large, independent board of 43 members</cite>.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the charity should <cite id="16">pursue a full BBB Wise Giving Alliance accreditation</cite> to verify all 20 standards of accountability.

impact.explanation: The Center demonstrates high efficiency with a <cite id="12">$0.12 cost per beneficiary</cite> and a <cite id="3">81.4% program ratio</cite>.
impact.improvement: Impact measurement would benefit from <cite id="15">tracking outcomes for 3+ years</cite> through external evaluations to verify long-term programmatic success.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Strong internal tracking with documented theory of change

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Funds a mix of domestic election reform and international health/peace partners.

rich_narrative.headline: The Carter Center Inc works to advance global peace and health through conflict resolution, democracy enhancement, and disease prevention.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who value long-term institutional stability and want to support the total eradication of specific global diseases through a high-capacity organization.
donor_motivations: Want to support legacy-driven humanitarian work
Value high-level diplomatic and peace-building efforts
Prefer organizations with massive financial security and low fundraising overhead
Interested in global health milestones like disease eradication
giving_considerations: The organization has very high reserves, meaning your gift is part of a large endowment-style pool
Focus is on high-level capacity building rather than local community-led aid
Not a faith-based organization, though its work aligns with universal humanitarian values
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking to fulfill specific Zakat obligations or those who prefer supporting smaller, grassroots organizations with immediate funding gaps.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects a clear theory of change and internal tracking, but a lack of independent, third-party impact evaluations.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The Center uses high-level diplomacy and technical health expertise to remove systemic barriers to peace and health.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Rigorous evidence ensures that large-scale interventions are achieving the intended health and peace outcomes efficiently.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: While the Center has high reserves, its <cite id="19">11.9% revenue growth</cite> shows increasing capacity for large-scale health projects.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by its <cite id="1">presidential founding</cite> and unique focus on <cite id="5">parasitic disease eradication</cite>.

similar_organizations.differentiator: More focused on direct healthcare delivery
similar_organizations.name: Save the Children Federation

strengths.detail: The organization maintains a highly efficient development model, spending just <cite id="7">$0.08 per $1 raised</cite>, well below industry averages.
The Center holds <cite id="10">91.0 months of working capital</cite>, providing extreme long-term stability for its multi-year health initiatives.
With a <cite id="3">81.4% program expense ratio</cite>, the vast majority of funding directly supports global peace and health programs.

strengths_deep_dive: The Carter Center's financial health is anchored by its massive asset base and efficient operations. The organization reported <cite id="11">total assets exceeding $1.15 billion</cite> in 2023, which supports its long-term mission. Its programmatic reach is significant, particularly in its health initiatives where it has achieved a <cite id="12">cost per beneficiary of approximately $0.12</cite> in specific contexts. Furthermore, the organization demonstrates strong governance through a <cite id="13">43-member board</cite> with <cite id="14">95% independent members</cite>, ensuring diverse oversight for its complex international operations.
rich_narrative.summary: The Carter Center, founded in <cite id="1">1982 by former U.S. President Jimmy Carter and Rosalynn Carter</cite>, is a major international institution dedicated to resolving conflicts and improving global health. The organization reported <cite id="2">$153,773,756 in total revenue</cite> for the 2023 fiscal year, maintaining a robust <cite id="3">program expense ratio of 81.4%</cite>. Its operations are divided into two primary pillars: Peace and Health. The Peace programs include the <cite id="4">Conflict Resolution and Democracy Programs</cite>, which monitor elections and mediate international disputes. The Health programs are renowned for their work in <cite id="5">Guinea worm disease eradication</cite>, which is on the verge of becoming the second human disease in history to be eliminated. Financed largely through <cite id="6">$114.1 million in public contributions</cite> and significant investment income, the Center operates with exceptional efficiency, spending only <cite id="7">$0.08 to raise every $1</cite> in donations. This lean fundraising model ensures that the vast majority of resources are directed toward its <cite id="8">international grantmaking and direct service delivery</cite>, which reached <cite id="9">111 foreign recipients</cite> in the most recent reporting period.
